newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan NEC says computer chip price slide has ended.
newsitem.headline: Japan NEC says computer chip price slide has ended.

text.p: Japan's NEC Corp said on Monday that a slide in computer memory chip prices had finally come to a halt, but too late to prevent it suffering sharply lower profits from the chip business this year.
"Prices of 16-megabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips have stabilised," Hajime Sasaki, senior executive vice president of the top chip maker, told a news conference.
"We anticipate the price of 16-megabit DRAMs for volume users will stay above $10 in the second half of the current business year as demand for memories will continue to be strong," Sasaki said.

Amid a supply glut following a worldwide slowdown in personal computer sales, prices of 16-megabit DRAM chips -- the current mainstay products used in PCs -- have nosedived more than 70 percent over the past ten months.
Most chip makers, worried by lower profits as well as charges that they are dumping chips at below market prices, began to curtail production after prices hit $8 in some sections of the spot market.
Sasaki said increased demand for PCs ahead of the Christmas season had provided the market with some relief, and there was now a supply shortage for some 16-megabit DRAM products.
He said a large fall in prices was unlikely in the January-March quarter, despite analysts' predictions that the market could fall once again after the holiday season.
He cited the Internet boom and increasing use of the memory-hungry Windows NT operating software as encouraging factors to boost demand for computer memories early next year.
"Last year, it was the Windows wave (that boosted demand for memories). I'm counting on the Internet wave this year," Sasaki said.

However, NEC's semiconductor production is expected to fall six percent to 1.1 trillion yen ($9.7 billion) in the 1996/97 business year to the end of next March, due to a market downturn early in the year, he said.
"We will see a considerable decline in profit in the chip business," Sasaki said, but declining to give a specific profit forecast.
In the April to September period, NEC suffered a four percent decline in the value of chip production against the year-earlier period, he said.

NEC will revise downward its planned capital investment in the microchip business for the year to end-March 1997 to 190 billion yen ($1.68 billion) from the 210 billion yen ($1.85 billion) it originally estimated, Sasaki said. ($1=113 yen)
